plants.name: Hamamelis virginiana
plants.description: Witch Hazel is a deciduous shrub native to eastern North America, known for its fragrant yellow flowers with crinkly petals that bloom in winter. It often flowers from late fall to early winter, making it one of the few plants blooming in cold climates during January.
plants.funFact: Witch Hazel extracts are commonly used in traditional medicine and skin care products due to their astringent properties.

plants.name: Camellia japonica
plants.description: A popular evergreen shrub cultivated widely for its showy flowers that bloom in winter. In mild climates, particularly in parts of East Asia and southeastern United States, Camellia japonica blooms from late fall through early spring, producing large, rose-like flowers.
plants.location: East Asia, Southeastern USA, Cultivated worldwide
plants.funFact: Camellia japonica flowers appear before the leaves fully develop, creating striking displays in winter gardens.

plants.name: Leptospermum scoparium
plants.description: A wild shrub native to New Zealand and southeast Australia, Manuka produces small white or pink flowers with numerous stamens. It often blooms in late summer through early winter in the Southern Hemisphere, corresponding to January in the Northern Hemisphere.
plants.funFact: Manuka honey, derived from these flowers, is prized worldwide for its unique antibacterial properties.

plants.name: Nerium oleander
plants.description: An evergreen shrub widely cultivated in Mediterranean and subtropical regions. Oleander blooms almost year-round in mild climates, including January, producing clusters of fragrant flowers in various colors.
plants.bloomingSeason: May to October, sometimes year-round in mild climates
plants.funFact: Despite its beauty, all parts of oleander are highly poisonous if ingested.
